Your steed understands when you choose to attack from a distance and remains steady, allowing you to perform tactical skills with less effort.
A sleek, high-backed saddle made of silk stretched over formed leather.
A striking, heavy-duty caparison made of silver-embroidered tapestry and sleek, shaped leather.
A durable green-and-gold metal plate made to hold a steed's tail neatly in place as he makes haste through the oceans of grass
The riders of Rohan thunder across the grassy seas of their homeland in silver and green. This caparison bears the image of a rampant white horse.
Sturdy iron ornaments of dwarf-make that won't come loose even in the heat of battle.

In his days as a captain in the King's guard, Ingbert and his steed rode to battle in magnificent armour like this. The full-body caparison bears the clean lines of a lyre, the symbol of Reeve Ingbert's house.
A practical halter of tough, cured leather and durable steel rings to keep a steed safe in the thrill of danger.
These reliable suede saddlebags are double-stitched and built to last. The tough black boots are helpful for times when you must ford marshy terrain on foot.
The Hunter's art is one of simple harmony with nature. Hunters carry only what they need to survive in the wild.
When a practical joke goes sour, a speedy getaway becomes necessary. These leather leg guards help a steed to fly to safety.
Simple, functional leg-guards built to protect a steed's sensitive shins.
As steed and rider fly to meet their foe, these green metal leg guards will cut through any brush that stands in their way.
These tough leg guards are meant for pushing aside the reeds and rushes that grow thickly in the Entwash marshes.
Quick-fingered Burglars get themselves into a great deal of mischief, and need lots of places to store their liberated treasures.
Cold and unsentimental winds blow across the faded grasses and lonely downs of the Entwash Vale. Practical leather halters like this help to protect a steed from the elements.
A Champion in battle-frenzy must press ever forward, deeper into the heart of battle. These Damascus leg guards help the Champion's steed carry him there.
The guards who protect Garsfeld, Snowbourn and Walstow bear this heraldry proudly as they ride their bounds.
A fierce eastern-make battle halter of tough leather beneath engraved silver plates.
A fancy full-body caparison made of intricately embroidered silk.
These simple leg-guards help to keep a steed's legs free of mud when working the fields after recent rain.
A tight gold wrapping accented with leather strips, perfect for keeping shorter tails clean.
A simple saddle, well-worn by years of use in the fields of the Eastemnet.
A heavy accessory from the people of the Wold
Dusky purple ribbon held in place by sturdy iron bolts.
Style and power combined into one efficient set of travel gear for warriors who cannot afford excess.
The essence of winter is woven into this striking caparison, threaded with veins of cold silver.
The vivid imagery of defeat is but an illusion to the Rune-keeper, secure in this high-backed wooden saddle and protected by crystal wards.
Strong is the warrior's heart, and so too is his armour. This shielded leather barding is made to last.
Behold the thunderous hoofbeats of your steed as you ride together over the weathered rock and withered grass.
A heavy accessory from the people of the Entwash.
These roomy saddlebags are of southern-make, and must have been claimed from a merchant caravan travelling north from Harad. They still smell of tea and spices.
This versatile assassin's set includes everything one needs to get the job done quickly and quietly. It is favoured by the shadowed figures who lurk in the corners of the Prancing Pony.
Many depend upon the Champion, who must fight on even through the red haze of battle. The Champion's steed, too, must be prepared to cut through the enemy defences.
The guards of Sutcrofts spare no details when outfitting their steeds for protection.
Black leather straps decorated with molded iron roses and set beneath a trailing. Embroidered saddle blanket.
Contoured leather leg guards like these once helped the Elves of the Greenwood to patrol their borders with efficiency and silence.
Formed leather is tough to come by, but not with this tail accessory.
A gaily-coloured pair of saddlebags bearing the lyre, the symbol of Reeve Ingbert's house.
An intricate, ceremonial saddle formed from black leather, traditional in Rohirric celebrations.
A brightly-coloured tail wrap made of red satin ribbon and gold beads.
Thranduil's archers once favoured armour in the colours of a newborn forest, and clothed their steeds in these as well.
Mounted combat can be touch and go at times, especially for those who favour knives. A flat, simple saddle allows for maximum manoeuvrability.
The silver stars upon these leggings flash brightly as the Lore-master's steed runs like a gust of wind toward new discoveries.
The Guardian carries only the essentialsâthose items that may help turn the tables in a seemingly impossible battle.
This halter is mostly used to show the heraldry of Cliving, but it affords the steed who wears it some protection, as well.
The solitary Eglain make use of whatever materials they can find. These rough saddlebags of antler and rawhide are an example of their resourcefulness.
To some, the road is a place between where you are and where you must go; to others, the road is home. This versatile gear set is made for a simple, easy life in the saddle.
A bold Easterling caparison set over sturdy black leather straps and embroidered with fine gold needlework.
It was Elbereth Gilthoniel who kindled the stars into being. Now a master craftsman has embroidered that starlight into these elegant saddlebags, that they might guide you wherever you go.
These flared leg guards add visual balance to the traditional battle-gear of Eaworth's steeds.
True heroics do not stem from battle acuity only, but also preparedness. Extra armour, blades, and rations can often make the difference between a failure and a legend.
When the Men of the Norcrofts are called to war, they dress their beloved steeds in decorative barding made for both strength and speed.
An elegant, high-backed saddled made in the likeness of an exotic bird.
A striking tail ornament of gilded leather.
Heavy leggings from the people of the Wold
These bold and festive saddlebags will leave no mystery about where your loyalties lie.
A dependable leather saddle is all the Guardian needs to catch a breath amidst a fight.
A sturdy, highly-decorated saddle of thick leather used by the vigilant guards of the Sutcrofts.
A high-backed, regulation saddle used by the soldiers of the Norcrofts.
A well-stitched, full halter made of coloured silk.
A light-weight and versatile leather saddle common in the Norcrofts.
A magnificent eastern-make caparison and delicately embroidered, quilted saddle blanket. Silver coins are strung from the engraved plates to bring good fortune to the warrior.

A simple set of saddlebags built for carrying only the essentials, meant for swift and urgent travel over long distances.
An intricate patterned saddle fashioned after the work of Dunlending weavers.

A mighty charge can overpower even the doughtiest of foes. These black leather leggings are near impervious to wear.

Quilted, embroidered leg guards made to provide support without adding weight.

Three diamond-shaped golden plates that look best on long, elegant tails.
A Lore-master studies ancient craft to better understand the past. Tomes, scrolls, and maps from elder days help her to find success in the present ones.
A number of sturdy bags with multiple compartments made to hold a travelling merchant's extensive inventory.
A fierce, heavy halter made of jagged leather and accented with veins of silver.
A striking saddle made of bright silk stitched onto formed black leather.
A sturdy, highly-decorated saddle of thick leather used by the vigilant guards of the Sutcrofts.

A fine leather saddle accented with silver filigree, used by the famed Riders of Rohan as they patrol the bounds of their beloved home.
The favoured trappings of the lone dissenter, he who sees the King's descent into dotage, and is not afraid to rebel against the wicked whisperings of GrÃ­ma Wormtongue.
Ceremonial, embroidered leggings used by Khundolar warriors to decorate their steeds.
A sturdy tail ornament with a turtle motif, inspired by Dunlending craft.

Shining silver scales that fit snugly on a war-steed's tail.

Mercenaries know the importance of being able to travel at a moment's notice. Their rough and simple belongings are all that is needed to earn a living by the sword.

Embroidered cloth leggings made for celebratory parades through the towns of the Estemnet.
Heavy metal ornaments designed to keep a tail hanging low and straight.

A heavy halter from the people of the Entwash.
Four strong, doeskin saddlebags that won't slip off during strenuous travel, and will keep gear dry through any downpour.

Two exotic saddlebags hung with bright orange tassels, and lined with the fur of a predatory cat.

Hammered metal flowers and shining purple ribbons that will keep your war-steed's tail stylish and clean.
The people of the Wold are Rohan's noble bulwark, forever keeping vigil against threats from across the Anduin.

Sturdy leather leg guards accented with colourful silk.
Light, comfortable saddles like this one are necessary for traversing the harsh and unpredictable terrain of the Wold.
Decorated formed leather that fits snugly on your war-steed's tail.
Overo is a term for a pinto coloured horse with distinct, irregular white-over-dark patterning on its hide. The darker patches can occur in any solid base colour.
A common spotted colour pattern common in pintos. The skin underneath the white-haired patches is pink in colour. Tobiano pelts are common, and do not fade as a horse ages.

A roan is any horse that has an even mix of dark and white hairs growing on its pelt. The lower legs, mane, and tail are usually darker in colour. Roan is a common coat colour, and can be found in many breeds.
A single-coloured pelt free of any distinct markings.
This spotted pelt is an Appaloosa variation that results from white being overlaid on top of base coat colours. It is a very old colouration, and occurs in many breeds.
A bay is characterized by black points on the legs, mane and tail. It is a base colour from which many other variations spring.

An incredibly rare horse colouring. It occurs when a horse or pony possesses both a dark base colour and a lighter shade on top of it, which gives the appearance of stripes on the neck, back, and hindquarters.
Dappled horses are covered in light spots that bring to mind mottled sunlight falling through a leafy canopy.
A fleabitten coat is a speckled pattern, usually light in colour, that occurs as a horse ages. It occurs when red-coloured hairs begin to grow on the horse's pelt, often in great abundance.
A festive motley blanket hung with tiny silver bells that chime out the melody of battle.
When desperate flight is necessary, these fur-lined leather leggings will not snag on treacherous roots or thorns.
Sturdy metal leg guards dyed a dark burgundy.
A mighty, heavy halter of burnished silver and rich, red velvet.
Cross-gartered leggings of silken ribbon that match the Minstrel's triumphant spirit.

Because the Captain must stand in harm's way to shelter her comrades, her steed, too, must be heavily armoured in well-oiled steel plate.
The wild places of Middle-earth are treacherous to the unprepared. The survivalist anticipates every need.

A store of essentials, such as cookware, a repair kit, and a spare shield, helps the Warden to persevere through hardship, expected or otherwise.

A set of simple instruments â lute, drum, bagpipes, and tambourine â that the Minstrel may use to raise the spirits even in the thick of battle.

A merry halter of motley and bright red ribbon for the steed who aids the Minstrel's noble cause.
A durable red-and-gold metal plate made to hold a steed's tail neatly in place.

A wine-red, formal caparison emblazoned with the bold Rohan sun.
This fine plate-and-tassel regalia suits the Warden, for whom battle is not a duty but a celebration of skill.
A fine leather saddle accented with silver filigree.
In battle the Warden is a wall of steel, and so too should be his steed. This strong plate mail provides a war-steed with weight and force enough to topple any foe.
This sleek halter keeps a steed's mane out of the way of snagging branches, and helps steed and rider to find the path in thick and shadowed undergrowth.
In a time of need, the Captain must have everything she requires, such as a bedroll and her helmet, within easy reach.
This bright flag leaves no question about for whose side you fight. As you ride to war, show your foes that Rohan is a force to be feared.
Let fly the colours of ThÃ©oden King! Show your enemies whose land it is they threaten, and assure it is the last thing they ever learn.
Let your War-steed's tail flow free and wild, the way it was meant to be.

Reduced Fate - DrÃ¡sa's Folk were a cruel people, and the Ring given to their king by Sauron led them into war against their kin. When the Dark Lord demanded the Ring's return, however, they refused, and his armies besieged and sacked their halls. The Enemy took many of the survivors back to Mordor as prisoners, forcing them to toil in the mines and pits of the Black Land for centuries. Stripped of their history, their clan name, and even their own language, they became a lost people. As years passed, they adopted a new clan name: the Stout-axes.

Reduced Fate - DrÃ¡sa's Folk were a cruel people, and the Ring given to their king by Sauron led them into war against their kin. When the Dark Lord demanded the Ring's return, however, they refused, and his armies besieged and sacked their halls. The Enemy took many of the survivors back to Mordor as prisoners, forcing them to toil in the mines and pits of the Black Land for centuries. Stripped of their history, their clan name, and even their own language, they became a lost people. As years passed, they adopted a new clan name: the Stout-axes.

Increased Might and Agility, improved resistance to Shadow and Disease - It is whispered that Sauron bred some among the Stout-axes using the same methods that had produced the mighty Uruk-hai and Olog-hai.
